bug.author: danielhers
bug.summary: is_oov returns True for common values of DEP, TAG, etc.
bug.description:
The semantics of is_oov are not entirely clear to me. Is it supposed to return True only for out-of-vocabulary words? What about other vocabulary elements? Example: <denchmark-code>>>> import spacy >>> nlp = spacy.load("en_core_web_lg") >>> doc = nlp("John loves Mary") >>> nlp.vocab[doc[0].dep].text 'nsubj' >>> nlp.vocab[doc[0].dep].is_oov True >>> nlp.vocab[doc[1].dep].text 'ROOT' >>> nlp.vocab[doc[1].dep].is_oov False </denchmark-code>
I suppose 'ROOT' is not out-of-vocabulary because it's also a word, while 'nsubj' isn't. My use-case is that I use spaCy for feature extraction for my classifier, and then I save the extracted feature matrix (of numeric IDs) to a file so I can use it later in training without even having to import spacy. I'd like to treat out-of-vocabulary symbols as "unknown", so my classifier won't even have to allocate elements for them in the embeddings lookup table. However, it seems like I can't use this strategy since I certainly don't want to treat 'nsubj' as "unknown". Should I just apply this rule only for ORTH and LEMMA features? <denchmark-h:h2>Info about spaCy</denchmark-h>
Python version: 3.5.2+ spaCy version: 2.0.5 Platform: Linux-4.8.4-aufs-1-x86_64-with-debian-stretch-sid Models: en_core_web_lg

comments.comment: Thanks for the report. Merging with <denchmark-link:https://github.com/explosion/spaCy/issues/1574>#1574</denchmark-link> as the underlying issue is the sme.
This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
